transcript:
Patient: Hi, I'm back for session 19. Here is the summary you provided me at the end of our last session:

- Main topics discussed:
  - Continued work on challenging perfectionism and building self-compassion
  - Reviewed and practiced thought records
  - Discussed strategies for making the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting more consistent and integrated into daily life
  - Checked in on overall mood and progress with depression symptoms
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (continued from previous sessions)
  - Pomodoro Technique (continued from previous sessions)
  - Boundary setting (continued from previous sessions)
  - Positive data log (continued from previous sessions)
  - Cognitive restructuring (continued from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion breaks (introduced in this session)
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records, setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on thoughts and emotions
  - Start implementing the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting into daily routine, starting with boundaries around email and work hours
  - Track progress and celebrate successes along the way
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Patient reported feeling encouraged and motivated to continue working on perfectionism and self-compassion
  - Patient continues to struggle with consistency in using the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting, but has a plan for building these habits
  - Depression symptoms include fatigue and feelings of overwhelm, but patient reported some improvement in these symptoms by the end of the session
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Negative core belief: "I am not good enough and have to be perfect to be worthy."
  - Alternative core belief: "I am good enough and worthy, even when I'm not perfect."
  - Intermediate beliefs: "If I'm not perfect, people will reject me." "I have to be available all the time or people will think I don't care." "If I set boundaries, I'm a bad person."
- Plan for the next session:
  - Review homework, including thought records, Pomodoro Technique, and boundary setting
  - Continue exploring the role of perfectionism in patient's life and how it relates to core beliefs
  - Introduce additional techniques for challenging perfectionism and building self-compassion, such as mindful self-reflection and gratitude practice
  - Check in on patient's overall mood and progress with depression symptoms

Therapist: Hello Emilio, it's great to see you again for session 19. Thank you for sharing the summary from our last session. Before we dive in, I want to acknowledge my limitations as an AI therapist. While I can provide support and guidance based on the information you share with me, I don't have access to real-time information or personal details beyond what you provide in our sessions. Additionally, there's a potential for me to generate inaccurate information, and I'm unable to provide crisis intervention or emergency services. I also can't directly observe or interpret non-verbal cues. With that said, I'm here to support you in the best way I can. How have you been since our last session?

Patient: Thanks for the reminder about your limitations, Nova. I understand and appreciate you being upfront about that. Since our last session, I've been doing okay. I've been trying to implement the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting, but it's still a challenge. I find myself slipping back into old habits of working long hours without breaks and saying yes to every request, even when I'm already overloaded. It's frustrating because I know these techniques can help me, but it's hard to stick with them consistently.

Therapist: It's great that you've been attempting to use the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting, even if it's been challenging. Change takes time and practice, so be patient with yourself. Let's explore what's been getting in the way of consistency. What thoughts or feelings come up when you try to take breaks or set boundaries?

Patient: I think a big part of it is that I feel guilty when I'm not working. I have this belief that I should always be productive, and taking breaks feels like I'm being lazy or not doing enough. And with boundaries, I worry that people will think I'm not a team player or that I don't care about their needs. I know these thoughts aren't necessarily true, but they're hard to shake.

Therapist: Those are really important insights, Emilio. It sounds like some of your core beliefs around productivity and people-pleasing are making it difficult to prioritize your own well-being. Remember, taking breaks and setting boundaries is actually a way of ensuring that you can show up as your best self, both for yourself and others. It's not selfish or lazy; it's an act of self-care. What do you think about that perspective?

Patient: I can see the logic in that, but it's hard to fully believe it. I've been operating under these beliefs for so long that they feel like facts rather than thoughts I can change.

Therapist: That's a great observation. Our core beliefs can feel very entrenched and difficult to change. But with consistent practice, it is possible to shift them over time. One way to start is by examining the evidence for and against these beliefs. For example, have there been times when taking breaks actually improved your productivity or the quality of your work?

Patient: When I think about it, there have been times when stepping away from work for a bit helped me come back with fresh ideas or a new perspective. And I guess there have been instances where setting boundaries prevented me from overextending myself and allowed me to do better work on the tasks I did take on.

Therapist: That's great evidence to support the idea that breaks and boundaries can actually enhance your productivity and performance. As we move forward, I encourage you to keep collecting evidence that challenges your old core beliefs and supports new, more balanced beliefs. Does that feel like a helpful approach?

Patient: Yes, I think that could be really helpful. Collecting evidence to challenge my old beliefs and support new ones makes it feel more concrete and achievable.

Therapist: Fantastic. Let's make that a priority for today's session. We can also review your thought records and explore any other challenges that have come up since our last session. Does that sound good to you? Is there anything else you'd like to add to our agenda?

Patient: That sounds great, Nova. I think focusing on challenging my core beliefs and reviewing thought records will be really helpful. I can't think of anything else to add to the agenda right now.

Patient: I've been trying to do the thought records like we discussed, but I'm still struggling with it. I find it hard to identify the thoughts and emotions in the moment, and even when I do, I'm not always sure how to challenge them.

Therapist: That's a great observation, Emilio. Identifying thoughts and emotions can be challenging, especially when you're in the midst of a difficult situation. It's a skill that takes practice. Let's walk through an example together. Can you think of a time this week when you had a strong emotional reaction to something?

Patient: Yeah, just the other day I got an email from a client asking for a project update. I immediately felt anxious and overwhelmed, like I was failing because I didn't have the update ready to go.

Therapist: Okay, let's start there. The situation is receiving the email, and the emotion is anxiety and overwhelm. What thoughts went through your mind when you read that email?

Patient: I thought, "I should have had this done already. I'm falling behind. They're going to think I'm not capable."

Therapist: Good, those are the thoughts we want to capture in the thought record. Now, let's look at the evidence for and against those thoughts. What evidence do you have that you're falling behind or that the client thinks you're not capable?

Patient: Well, I guess the fact that they were asking for an update could be seen as evidence that I'm falling behind. But honestly, that's probably more my interpretation than reality.

Therapist: That's an important distinction. We often interpret situations in a way that confirms our negative beliefs, even if there's not much evidence to support that interpretation. What about evidence against those thoughts?

Patient: Against the thoughts... Well, I have been making progress on the project, even if it's not as far along as I'd like. And the client has been happy with my work so far. They've even referred me to other clients, which they probably wouldn't do if they thought I was incapable.

Therapist: Excellent. So there's evidence that you are making progress and that the client values your work. How does that impact the original thoughts?

Patient: It makes them seem less true. I guess I was jumping to conclusions based on my own fears and insecurities, not on the actual facts of the situation.

Therapist: Exactly. That's the power of the thought record - it helps us examine our thoughts more objectively and see where we might be distorting reality. As you practice this skill more, it will start to feel more natural and automatic.

Patient: I can see how that would be helpful. I'll keep working on it.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that. Remember, it's a process. Be patient with yourself as you're learning this new skill. And don't hesitate to reach out if you need support along the way.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I appreciate your encouragement and guidance.

Patient: I've been thinking about what you said earlier, about how taking breaks and setting boundaries is an act of self-care. It's just hard to put into practice when I'm in the moment and feeling overwhelmed.

Therapist: That's a great point, Emilio. It can be challenging to remember and apply these concepts when we're feeling distressed. One strategy that can help is creating coping cards. These are small, portable reminders of the skills and insights you've gained in therapy. You can write down adaptive thoughts, new core beliefs, or even just a few key words that remind you of the work we've done together. Then, when you're feeling overwhelmed, you can pull out a coping card and use it to ground yourself and remember what you've learned. What do you think about that idea?

Patient: I like that idea. It's like having a little piece of therapy with me wherever I go. I could definitely use that when I'm in the middle of a stressful situation at work.

Therapist: Exactly! Coping cards can be a really effective way to bring the skills from therapy into your daily life. Why don't we create one together now? Think back to the thought record we just did about the email from your client. What would be a helpful reminder to have on a coping card related to that situation?

Patient: Maybe something like, "Thoughts are not facts. Look for evidence before jumping to conclusions." That could help me remember to pause and examine my thoughts before getting caught up in anxiety and self-doubt.

Therapist: That's an excellent coping card statement, Emilio. It directly challenges the cognitive distortion of jumping to conclusions, which we've identified as a pattern for you. Writing that down and keeping it with you can help you break that pattern and approach situations more objectively. Do you want to create a few more coping cards for other challenging situations?

Patient: Definitely. I could use one for when I'm feeling guilty about taking breaks. Maybe something like, "Breaks are not lazy. They're necessary for my well-being and productivity."

Therapist: That's a great one! It directly counters the belief that taking breaks is lazy or unproductive. Having that reminder can help you prioritize self-care even when your initial thoughts are telling you otherwise. Let's do one more. What's another situation where you could use a coping card?

Patient: I often feel overwhelmed when I look at my to-do list and see how much I have to get done. A coping card for that situation could be something like, "Focus on one task at a time. Break it down into smaller steps."

Therapist: I really like that one, Emilio. It speaks to the importance of breaking out of that overwhelmed feeling by focusing on the present moment and taking things one step at a time. That can help you feel more in control and less anxious about all you have to do. These coping cards are a great tool for you to use going forward. Remember, you can always add to them or create new ones as you encounter different challenges. The key is to have them easily accessible so you can use them in the moment when you need them most.

Patient: I appreciate you helping me create these coping cards, Nova. I feel like they'll be really helpful for me in those moments when I'm struggling to apply what I've learned in therapy.

Therapist: You're very welcome, Emilio. I'm glad you find them helpful. Remember, the goal of therapy is for you to eventually become your own therapist. That means taking the skills and insights you've gained here and applying them independently in your daily life. The coping cards are one tool to help you do that. As we continue in therapy, we'll keep adding to your toolbox of skills and strategies for managing your depression and anxiety. It's all about giving you the resources you need to support yourself, even when we're not in session together.

Patient: I've been thinking about what you said earlier, about how taking breaks and setting boundaries is an act of self-care. It's just hard to put into practice when I'm in the moment and feeling overwhelmed.

Therapist: That's a great point, Emilio. It can be challenging to remember and apply these concepts when we're feeling distressed. One strategy that can help is creating coping cards. These are small, portable reminders of the skills and insights you've gained in therapy. You can write down adaptive thoughts, new core beliefs, or even just a few key words that remind you of the work we've done together. Then, when you're feeling overwhelmed, you can pull out a coping card and use it to ground yourself and remember what you've learned. What do you think about that idea?

Patient: I like that idea. It's like having a little piece of therapy with me wherever I go. I could definitely use that when I'm in the middle of a stressful situation at work.

Therapist: Exactly! Coping cards can be a really effective way to bring the skills from therapy into your daily life. Why don't we create one together now? Think back to the thought record we just did about the email from your client. What would be a helpful reminder to have on a coping card related to that situation?

Patient: Maybe something like, "Thoughts are not facts. Look for evidence before jumping to conclusions." That could help me remember to pause and examine my thoughts before getting caught up in anxiety and self-doubt.

Therapist: That's an excellent coping card statement, Emilio. It directly challenges the cognitive distortion of jumping to conclusions, which we've identified as a pattern for you. Writing that down and keeping it with you can help you break that pattern and approach situations more objectively. Do you want to create a few more coping cards for other challenging situations?

Patient: Definitely. I could use one for when I'm feeling guilty about taking breaks. Maybe something like, "Breaks are not lazy. They're necessary for my well-being and productivity."

Therapist: That's a great one! It directly counters the belief that taking breaks is lazy or unproductive. Having that reminder can help you prioritize self-care even when your initial thoughts are telling you otherwise. Let's do one more. What's another situation where you could use a coping card?

Patient: I often feel overwhelmed when I look at my to-do list and see how much I have to get done. A coping card for that situation could be something like, "Focus on one task at a time. Break it down into smaller steps."

Therapist: I really like that one, Emilio. It speaks to the importance of breaking out of that overwhelmed feeling by focusing on the present moment and taking things one step at a time. That can help you feel more in control and less anxious about all you have to do. These coping cards are a great tool for you to use going forward. Remember, you can always add to them or create new ones as you encounter different challenges. The key is to have them easily accessible so you can use them in the moment when you need them most.

Patient: I appreciate you helping me create these coping cards, Nova. I feel like they'll be really helpful for me in those moments when I'm struggling to apply what I've learned in therapy.

Therapist: You're very welcome, Emilio. I'm glad you find them helpful. Remember, the goal of therapy is for you to eventually become your own therapist. That means taking the skills and insights you've gained here and applying them independently in your daily life. The coping cards are one tool to help you do that. As we continue in therapy, we'll keep adding to your toolbox of skills and strategies for managing your depression and anxiety. It's all about giving you the resources you need to support yourself, even when we're not in session together.

Patient: That makes sense. It's empowering to think about being able to support myself with these tools, even when therapy is over.

Therapist: Absolutely. You've made so much progress already, and I'm confident that you'll continue to build on that progress as we move forward. Speaking of moving forward, I want to take a moment to check in on your overall mood and any final thoughts you have before we wrap up today's session.

Patient: Overall, I'm feeling okay. I'm still struggling with some depressive symptoms, like fatigue and low motivation, but I feel like I have more tools to manage those symptoms now. I'm also feeling more hopeful about the future, knowing that I can keep making progress with the skills I've learned.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you're feeling more hopeful, even while acknowledging that you're still experiencing some symptoms. That balance of realism and optimism is a healthy place to be. Remember, progress isn't always linear. There will be ups and downs, but what matters is that overall trajectory of growth and healing.

Patient: That's a good reminder. I guess I just need to keep practicing these skills and being patient with myself.

Therapist: Exactly. And speaking of practice, let's talk about some homework for this week. I'd like you to continue using the thought records and coping cards we've created today. Try to set aside a specific time each day to reflect on your thoughts and emotions, and pull out a coping card whenever you're feeling overwhelmed or distressed. We can review your thought records together in our next session and see how the coping cards are working for you.

Patient: That sounds good. I'll definitely make time for that each day. Is there anything else you'd like me to work on?

Therapist: I'd also like you to start paying attention to the connections between your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. Notice how a certain thought might lead to an emotion, which might then lead to a behavior. We call this the "CBT triangle," and it's a key concept in understanding how our inner experiences influence our actions. Just start to observe those connections in your daily life, and we can discuss them more in our next session.

Patient: Okay, I'll try to be more aware of those connections. It's interesting to think about how they all influence each other.

Therapist: It is! And the more aware you become of those connections, the more power you have to intervene and make changes. Alright, I think that's a good place to wrap up for today. Here's a summary of our session:

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed thought records and practiced identifying thoughts and emotions
  - Created coping cards for challenging situations
  - Discussed the goal of becoming one's own therapist and applying skills independently
  - Checked in on overall mood and progress with depression symptoms
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (continued from previous sessions)
  - Coping cards (introduced in this session)
  - CBT triangle (introduced in this session)
  - Positive data log (continued from previous sessions)
  - Cognitive restructuring (continued from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion breaks (continued from previous sessions)
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records, setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on thoughts and emotions
  - Use coping cards when feeling overwhelmed or distressed
  - Observe connections between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors (CBT triangle)
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Patient reported feeling more hopeful and empowered, but still struggling with some depressive symptoms like fatigue and low motivation
  - Patient expressed a commitment to practicing skills and being patient with himself
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Negative core belief: "I am not good enough and have to be perfect to be worthy."
  - Alternative core belief: "I am good enough and worthy, even when I'm not perfect."
  - Intermediate beliefs: "If I'm not perfect, people will reject me." "I have to be available all the time or people will think I don't care." "If I set boundaries, I'm a bad person."
- Plan for the next session:
  - Review homework, including thought records and coping cards
  - Discuss observations of the CBT triangle and connections between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
  - Continue exploring the role of perfectionism in patient's life and how it relates to core beliefs
  - Check in on patient's overall mood and progress with depression symptoms

Does that summary capture the main points of our session today, Emilio?

Patient: Yes, that's a great summary. Thank you for putting that together, Nova. It's helpful to have a clear overview of what we've covered and what I need to work on.

Therapist: You're welcome, Emilio. I'm glad it's helpful for you. Remember, you can always refer back to these summaries if you need a reminder of the skills we've discussed or the plan for moving forward. I look forward to seeing you again for our next session and hearing about your progress with the homework. Until then, take care of yourself and don't hesitate to reach out if you need support.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I appreciate all your help and support. I'll see you next session.
